newsitem.title: UK: LIFFE cocoa rides on strong grinds, shaves gains.
newsitem.headline: LIFFE cocoa rides on strong grinds, shaves gains.

text.p: London cocoa futures were propelled by surprisingly high European third quarter grind figures but origin and scale-up trade selling trimmed gains before the close.
Traders noted short-covering and trade-related buying on the back of strong Dutch and UK grind data released in early hours of the session. A small dose of industry buying was also cited.
Volume was relatively limited with many players travelling to Paris for an annual trade dinner. But traders were impressed by Friday's price reversal after four consecutive days of losses.

"Considering how bad the market has been performing, 10 stg-up is important," said one trader, referring to the benchmark March contract before the close. Minutes after the grind news, March rose to a high of 1,000 stg a tonne and hovered just below that level throughout most of the session. It pared gains slightly in late dealings, ending seven stg up from Thursday at 992 stg.
Turnover was relatively thin at 3,602 lots.
The UK grind, up 42 percent from a year ago at 48,855 tonnes, outpaced even the wildest guesses. One industry estimate last week of around 20 percent was said to be conditional.

But the rise was believed to have been partly helped by the resumption of production at a major plant of top UK chocolate manufacturer Mars. The year-ago grindings, the worst quarter in 1995, were affected by the closure of that plant.
The Dutch grind rose an impressive 16.69 percent to 99,549 tonnes in the third quarter against market expectations of around 10 percent.
"It's a hell of a grind," said one trader. "It's very, very bullish."
Switches were quiet on Friday, but the Dec/March spread was bid up slightly after Thursday's 25-26 stg.
Technically, the market remains in a downtrend until gains are extended above the 1,025 resistance, analysts said.
